docs.lead_paragraph: How accurate are infrared thermometers that measure temperature through the ears? Accurate enough for a parent trying to decide whether a child has a fever, but not accurate enough for an emergency room physician in a situation that calls for getting it just right, according to a study published on Saturday in The Lancet. Researchers from the University of Liverpool collected data from 44 studies that compared readings from infrared ear thermometers and rectal thermometers, which are widely considered the most accurate way to measure core temperature. The team found that the average difference between the two methods was relatively small, about a half-degree Fahrenheit.

headline.main: In the Ear and Off the Mark

docs.abstract: University of Liverpool researchers, in study published in Lancet, finds that infrared thermometers that measure temperature in ear are not accurate enough for emergency room physicians to make accurate assessments; drawing (M)
